questions.question: Match the following: 1. Durham’s rule a. A person is not guilty because of insanity if they were unaware of the nature, quality, and consequences of their acts or could not realise they were wrong. 2. Curren’s rule b. An accused is not criminally responsible if their unlawful act is the product of mental disease or defect. 3. McNaughten’s rule c. An accused is not criminally responsible if, at the time of the act, they couldn’t regulate their conduct due to mental disease or defect.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a Explanation: Rules related to Criminal responsibility: Durham’s rule An accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of a mental disease or mental defect. Later, this rule was discarded in the USA. Curren’s rule An accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect. McNaughten’s rule (Section 84, IPC, Section 22, BNS ) A person is not criminally responsible if, due to a mental disease, they were unaware of the nature and consequences of their actions or unable to recognise that the act was wrong . It has the following requirements: There must be evidence of a mental disorder. The mental disorder must be present at the time of the crime. The disorder must impair the individual's ability to understand the wrongfulness or illegality of the act. Section 85 IPC (Section 23 BNS) A person who is intoxicated may not be criminally responsible if they were so impaired at the time of the act that they could not understand the nature of their actions or recognize that their actions were wrong or illegal. This applies only if the intoxication was caused against their will or without their knowledge. Section 86 IPC (Section 24 BNS) A voluntarily intoxicated person is still considered criminally responsible if they had the intention or knowledge to commit a crime, despite their intoxication. Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page 2657, 2659. Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 416, 417.

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman with severe depression and anxiety relapses due to job loss and a breakup. She expresses suicidal thoughts, prompting her therapist to suggest a treatment plan with advanced directives. Which of the following statements is included in advance directives under the Mental Health Act 2017? Every person, including minors, has the right to make a written advance directive. The individual can specify how they wish to be treated for a mental illness. The individual can specify how they wish not to be treated for a mental illness. Advance directives are applicable in emergency treatment situations.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 2,3 Explanation: Advance directives of the Mental Health Care Act, 2017: Every person who is not a minor can create an advance directive. (Statement 1 ruled out) Individuals can specify how they wish to be treated for a mental illness. (Statement 2) Individuals can specify how they do not want to be treated for a mental illness. (Statement 3) Individuals can appoint a nominated representative. The nominated representative's role is activated only when the individual loses the capacity to make decisions. The psychiatrist or medical officer in charge of treatment is responsible for ensuring that care aligns with the patient's advance directive. The patient, caregiver, or nominated representative is responsible for providing access to the advance directive for the psychiatrist or medical officer in charge. The doctor cannot be held liable if unforeseen consequences arise from following a valid advance directive. Advance directives are not applicable in emergency treatment situations. (Statement 4 ruled out) . Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 2702. https://mhca2017.com/index.php/act/chapter-iii-advance-directive#ad

questions.question: According to the Mental Health Care Act (MHCA) 2017, which section deals with the admission of minors to a mental health establishment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Section 87 Explanation: According to the Mental Health Care Act (MHCA) 2017 , Section 87 pertains to the admission of minors to a mental health establishment. Admission of patients with mental illness: Independent Admission: This is when an individual voluntarily seeks admission for treatment. Section 86 (Option A) Any person who is not a minor and believes they have a mental illness may request admission as an independent patient to a mental health establishment. This provision emphasizes the right of individuals to seek treatment voluntarily. Section 87 (Option B) Addresses the admission of minors to mental health establishments, ensuring that their rights and needs are specifically considered. Supported Admission: An individual who requires admission due to threats or attempts of bodily harm to themselves or others, or who is unable to care for themselves and has lost the capacity to make decisions regarding their mental healthcare or treatment. A nominated representative can provide consent for the admission. Section 89 (Option C) Admission and treatment for individuals with mental illness requiring high levels of support can be provided for up to 30 days. Section 90 (Option D) Admission and treatment for individuals with mental illness requiring high levels of support may extend beyond 30 days. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6482688/#:~:text=According%20to%20Section%2086% 20of,patient%20will%20benefit%20from%20admission . https://mhca2017.com/index.php/act/chapter-xii-admission-treatment-and-discharge

questions.question: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the decriminalisation of suicide in India as per the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017?

options.A: Suicide attempts were decriminalised as per IPC Section 309
options.B: The act provides treatment instead of punishment for suicide attempts.
options.C: Individuals who attempt suicide are presumed to have severe stress under the Act.
options.D: The Act encourages individuals to seek help without fear of legal consequences.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Suicide attempts were decriminalised as per IPC Section 309 Explanation: Prior to the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017 Indian Penal Code (IPC) Section 309: Attempting suicide was historically a criminal offence in India, punishable by imprisonment, fine, or both. This criminalisation treated suicide attempts as violations of law rather than issues of mental health. Change with the Mental Healthcare Act, 2017 Section 115 explicitly states that individuals who attempt suicide shall not be punished under IPC Section 309. (Option B ruled out) Instead, they are presumed to be experiencing severe stress linked to mental illness (Option C ruled out) and should receive care, treatment, and rehabilitation to prevent recurrence. This shift promotes a compassionate, health-centric approach , emphasizing the need for psychiatric help rather than imprisonment. Mental healthcare professionals are now mandated to provide appropriate psychosocial support and treatment for underlying mental health conditions. This act also helps reduce the stigma associated with mental illness, encouraging individuals to seek help without fear of legal repercussions. (Option D ruled out) Reference: Gautam Biswas, Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Edition 3, Page 298

questions.question: A 12-year-old girl presents with social withdrawal, anxiety, and bruises. She discloses inappropriate behaviour by her neighbour, and examination reveals signs of possible sexual abuse. What should the healthcare provider do immediately?

options.A: Refer the patient to a psychiatrist for evaluation.
options.B: Document the findings and schedule a follow-up appointment.
options.C: Report the suspected abuse to the appropriate authorities.
options.D: Discuss the situation with the patient’s parents before taking any action

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Report the suspected abuse to the appropriate authorities. Explanation: When a healthcare provider suspects sexual abuse in a child, the immediate action is to report the suspected abuse to the appropriate authorities. Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 , individuals aware of an incident of child sexual abuse are legally required to inform the local police or the Special Juvenile Police Unit. Failure to do so is considered a punishable offence. This Act aims to strengthen the protection of children below 18 years from sexual abuse, encompassing both male and female victims. The following offences are covered: Penetrative Sexual Assault Sexual Assault Sexual Harassment Use of a Child in Pornography Refer the patient to a psychiatrist for evaluation (Option A): Psychiatric evaluation is important for the child's mental health, it should occur after reporting. Document the findings and schedule a follow-up appointment (Option B): Documentation and follow-up are also necessary but must be secondary to ensuring the child's safety by reporting the abuse. Discuss the situation with the patient’s parents before taking any action (Option D): Discussing the situation with the parents before reporting can compromise the investigation and may put the child at further risk. Reference: Gautam Biswas, Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 3rd Edition, Page 38 India Code, Section 5 Link

questions.question: Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, which of the following scenarios would not be classified as an "aggravated" offence?

options.A: Security guard exploits his position of trust to abuse a child under his care.
options.C: Parent inflicts grievous hurt on their child
options.D: Peer shares explicit photos of a 15-year-old child

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Peer shares explicit photos of a 15-year-old child Explanation: Sharing explicit photos does not meet the criteria for an aggravated offence under POCSO, as it involves sharing content without direct harm or abuse. Aggravated Offence in POCSO: An offence is considered "aggravated" under the following circumstances: Perpetrated by an individual in a position of trust or authority over the child (e.g., security personnel, police officers, public servants, jail staff). Involves a gang. Involves the use of deadly weapons. Causes grievous hurt. Inflicts life-threatening diseases (e.g., HIV). Involves attempted murder. It is resulting in the child becoming mentally ill. Causes pregnancy in a female child. When it is committed repeatedly. Involves a child under 12 years of age. Occurs during communal or sectarian violence. Reference: Gautam Biswas, Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Edition 3, Page 38 India Code, section 5 Link

questions.question: A 62-year-old man recently lost his spouse and has been experiencing a profound sense of loss, sadness, and withdrawal from social interactions. This emotional response occurs following the death of a loved one and includes a natural period of adjustment. What term best describes his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Bereavement Explanation: Bereavement refers to the state of having lost someone close, typically following a death. It encompasses the emotional and psychological responses that occur during the process of adapting to the loss. Term Definition Characteristics Bereavement State of having lost someone close, typically due to death. Involves emotional and psychological responses; natural adjustment period; mild, transient functional impairment. Rarely involves severe symptoms like guilt or suicidal ideation. Mourning (Option A) The outward expression and rituals associated with grief after a loss. Includes cultural and personal expressions of grief; may involve ceremonies, rituals, and social mourning practices. Adjustment Disorder (Option B) A condition characterized by difficulty coping with a significant life stressor. Emotional or behavioral symptoms occur within three months of the event; can lead to distress and impaired functioning but not a normal grieving process. Depression (Option C) A mental health disorder marked by persistent sadness and loss of interest in activities. Symptoms include severe sadness, worthlessness, suicidal thoughts, and lack of interest; distinct from normal bereavement processes. Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 2674, 2675, 2680, 2682 Chapter 29, End of life issues and palliative care, subtopic - Bereavement, Grief and Mourning.

questions.question: A 62-year-old man is navigating the emotional process following the death of his spouse. Which of the following sequences best represents the stages of grief according to Kübler-Ross’s model? → Anger → Bargaining → Depression → Acceptance → Anger → Depression → Bargaining → Acceptance → Depression → Bargaining → Anger → Acceptance → Depression → Anger → Bargaining → Acceptance
questions.explanation: → Anger → Bargaining → Depression → Acceptance Correct Answer: A) Shock and Denial → Anger → Bargaining → Depression → Acceptance despair, and longing for the deceased. It may also include a range of emotions and behaviours influenced by cultural and personal factors. Stages of Grief/Death and Dying: Kübler-Ross identified five common stages of emotional responses to impending death/Grief. Stage 1- Shock and Denial: Patients initially react with disbelief and may seek multiple opinions to validate their denial. Effective communication from healthcare providers is essential to reassure and inform patients and families. Stage 2- Anger: Patients often feel frustrated and angry as reality sets in, questioning their fate and sometimes blaming others. Providers should approach this anger with empathy, recognising it as a natural response. Stage 3- Bargaining: IIIIIII Patients may negotiate with healthcare providers or a higher power, promising to change behaviours for a better outcome. Reassuring them of comprehensive care, regardless of their actions, is crucial. Stage 4- Depression: IIIIIII Signs of clinical depression can emerge, including withdrawal and hopelessness. While some sadness is normal, significant depressive symptoms should be treated to maintain quality of life and hope. Stage 5- Acceptance: IIIIIII In this stage, patients accept their mortality, & realise death is inevitable. Open discussions about death can occur, and spiritual beliefs may provide comfort. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK507885/ Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Pages 2668, 2669, 2670 Chapter 29: End-of-Life Issues and Palliative Care, Stages of Death and Dying.

questions.question: Which of the following is least aligned with the SPIKES protocol?

options.A: Addressing the patient's emotions with empathetic responses
options.B: Use complex medical jargon to explain the situation
options.C: Creating a private setting for the discussion
options.D: Start by asking about the patient’s understanding of the condition

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Use complex medical jargon to explain the situation Explanation: Using complex medical jargon contradicts the SPIKES protocol, emphasising clear and understandable communication. SPIKES Protocol: A Structured approach for delivering bad news to patients It focuses on 6 Steps: S-Setting Up the Interview Preparation : Rehearse and anticipate emotional responses. Privacy : Ensure a distraction-free environment (Option C) Involve Others : Let the patient choose participants. Relaxing Atmosphere & Connect with the patient P-Patient's Perception Understanding : Ask about the patient's grasp of their condition (Option D) Correct Misunderstandings : Clarify misconceptions. Identify Denial : Look for signs of denial or unrealistic expectations I-Patient's Invitation Information preferences: Inquire about the extent of information the patient wishes to receive regarding their diagnosis and prognosis & respect their preferencce K—Knowledge & Information Warning Before Bad News : Indicate difficult news is coming. Simple Language : Use clear, non-technical terms. (Option B) Gradual Delivery : Provide information in small chunks. E-Patient's Emotions Observe Emotions : Acknowledge emotional responses. Acknowledge Feelings : Use empathetic statements (Option A) Encourage Expression : Allow time for feelings to be expressed. Validate Responses : Reassure that reactions are normal S-Strategy and Summary Future Plans : Discuss readiness for treatment options. Collaborative Decision-Making : Involve the patient in planning. Clarify Understanding : Summarize to ensure comprehension Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10964998/ https://academic.oup.com/oncolo/article/5/4/302/6386019?login=false
